content:
Section notes for Intermediate Microeconomic Theory, ECON 401, with Professor Tilman Börgers
 Happy Labor Market Friday, valuing time, the rationality hypothesis, the transitive property, choices and consistent rankings CES utility functions, convex preferences, depicting indifference curves Checking rationality continued, demand functions, Cobb–Douglas preferences, monotonic transformations, more CES preferences Income and substitution effects, in pictures, numerically calculating the income and substitution effects, the sign of the substitution effect Marshalian demand, elasticities, Hicksian (compensated) demand, verifying that the Slutsky equation holds Comparative statics: prices, complements and substitutes, perfect complements, perfect complements, slightly imperfect substitutes, slightly imperfect complements Hicksian demand with perfect substitutes, labor supply, labor supply with perfect substitutes, labor-supply elasticity Firms’ profit maximization, isoquants, cost minimization, cost minimization with Cobb–Douglas technology, conditional factor demand functions Cost functions and returns to scale, \(p \geq \min \text{AC}(q) \), returns to scale and Cobb–Douglas Exam review, quadratic marginal cost, circle isoquants Equilibrium supply and demand, taxes, it doesn’t matter who pays the tax, taxation with linear demand and supply, nonlinear demand and elasticities: \[ \frac{d p}{d \tau} = \frac{\eta}{\eta + \varepsilon}\] Equilibrium in several interacting markets, partial equilibrium Equilibrium in several markets continued, short- vs long-run cost The change in consumer surplus, the slope of the demand curve, compensating variation, equivalent variation, for normal goods: \[ \text{EV} < \text{CS loss} < \text{CV}, \] for quasilinear utility: EV = CV Markets and efficiency; EV = old prices, new utility; CV = new prices, old utility; with transfers, all agents prefer equilibrium to all other allocations; equivalent and compensating variation with perfect complements and linear utility Tax incidence analysis: deadweight loss, Professor Börgers’s milk farm, Arrow’s Impossibility theorem, the Condorcet cycle Monopoly, the markup: \[\frac{P(Q)}{\text{MC}(Q)} = \frac{1}{1- 1/ |\varepsilon|}, \] first-degree price discrimination Price discrimination: first-, second-, and third-degree price discrimination, sale in different markets, \[p_1 > p_2 \iff |\varepsilon_1| < |\varepsilon_2|, \] Professor Börgers’s cat farm A very brief introduction to game theory, Nash equilibrium, chicken, modified picnic, modified traffic, beauty contest Game theory continued: Bertrand and Cournot, Braess’s paradox, Bertrand with differentiated products Risk and uncertainty, lotteries, St. Petersburg paradox, concavity and risk aversion, von Neumann Morgenstern utility function Externalities, a negative externality in consumption, strategic interaction and externalities The picnic example continued, moral hazard, thanks

summary:
Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. The charts are based on this NY Times article, which begins “The American economy plunged deeper into crisis last month, losing 20.5 million jobs as the unemployment rate jumped to 14.7 percent, the worst devastation since the Great Depression.”
The R code shared below replicates some of the charts included in the article. The charts are listed in the table of contents.
title: Labor Market Friday

content:
Here are a few facts from the most recent Employment Situation, inspired by two recent posts.
The first post from Brookings highlights the latest data on labor-force participation. The labor-force participation rate and the employment-population ratio are depicted below.
# Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) # Data for recession shading recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") tail(recess)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01 0 ## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01 0 ## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01 0 ## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01 0 ## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01 0 ## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01 0  recess_dat <- recess %>% arrange(date) %>% mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% # Filter only recessions filter(price == 1) recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% group_by(era) %>% # Unncessary, but to be sure... arrange(date) %>% filter(row_number() == 1 | row_number() == n()) # Now reshape the data wide. # Each row will contain the start and end dates of a recession. recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% mutate(junk = row_number()) %>% mutate(begin_end = case_when( junk == 1 ~ "begin", junk == 2 ~ "end" )) recess_wide <- recess_dat %>% ungroup() %>% select(symbol, price, date, era, begin_end) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = begin_end, values_from = date) dat <- tq_get(c("CIVPART", "EMRATIO"), get = "economic.data", from = "1900-01-01") # Name series dat <- dat %>% mutate(Series = case_when( symbol == "CIVPART" ~ "Labor-force participation rate", symbol == "EMRATIO" ~ "Employment-population ratio" )) dat2plt <- dat %>% mutate(last = date == max(date)) ggplot() + geom_path(data = dat2plt, mapping = aes(x = date, y = price, color = Series), key_glyph = "timeseries") + geom_point(filter(dat2plt, last == 1), mapping = aes(x = date, y = price)) + labs(x = "", y = "Percent") + geom_rect(data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat2plt$date)), mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf), fill = "blue", alpha = 0.2) + theme_bw()  In the second post, GREG MANKIW’S BLOG: Random Observations for Students of Economics compares the number of job losers on temporary layoff to the number of permanent job losers. To facilitate the comparison between the two job-loss series, I indexed the previous month to 100 for both series. (I stole the title of this post from the Mankiw post.)
The job-loss series are depicted below. To make the graph, it is important to know that both series are available at a monthly frequency, seasonally adjusted, and quoted in thousands of persons.
loss_series <- c("LNS13023653", "LNS13026638") loss <- tq_get(loss_series, get = "economic.data", from = "1900-01-01") head(loss)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 LNS13023653 1967-01-01 381 ## 2 LNS13023653 1967-02-01 355 ## 3 LNS13023653 1967-03-01 375 ## 4 LNS13023653 1967-04-01 420 ## 5 LNS13023653 1967-05-01 414 ## 6 LNS13023653 1967-06-01 418  tail(loss)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 LNS13026638 2019-10-01 1260 ## 2 LNS13026638 2019-11-01 1422 ## 3 LNS13026638 2019-12-01 1295 ## 4 LNS13026638 2020-01-01 1289 ## 5 LNS13026638 2020-02-01 1279 ## 6 LNS13026638 2020-03-01 1456  # Grab the 2nd-to-last date, uneloquently last2 <- nth(loss$date, -2L) dat_loss <- loss %>% group_by(symbol) %>% mutate(index_maker = max(price*(date == last2)), index = 100*price/index_maker) %>% mutate(`Unemployment level` = case_when( symbol == "LNS13023653" ~ "Job losers on layoff", symbol == "LNS13026638" ~ "Permanent job losers" )) ggplot(filter(dat_loss, date >= ymd("2015-01-01"))) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = index, color = `Unemployment level`), key_glyph = "timeseries") + labs(x = "", y = paste0("Index (", month(last2, label = TRUE), " ", year(last2), "= 100)")) + theme_bw()  And zooming out:
ggplot() + geom_path(data = dat_loss, mapping = aes(x = date, y = price, color = `Unemployment level`)) + geom_rect(data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat_loss$date)), mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf), fill = "blue", alpha = 0.2) + labs(x = "", y = "Thousands of persons") + theme_bw()
summary:
Here are a few facts from the most recent Employment Situation, inspired by two recent posts.
The first post from Brookings highlights the latest data on labor-force participation. The labor-force participation rate and the employment-population ratio are depicted below.
# Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) # Data for recession shading recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") tail(recess)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01 0 ## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01 0 ## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01 0 ## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01 0 ## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01 0 ## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01 0  recess_dat <- recess %>% arrange(date) %>% mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% # Filter only recessions filter(price == 1) recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% group_by(era) %>% # Unncessary, but to be sure.
title: Facts from the Employment Situation

content:
Here are the latest data that depict the negative relationship between unemployment and job vacancies. The scatter plot of unemployment rates versus vacancy rates is known as the Beveridge curve.
# Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) library(viridis) mygray <- "gray66" # Data series my_series <- c("JTSJOL", "PAYEMS", "UNRATE") dat <- tq_get(my_series, get = "economic.data", from = "1900-01-01") print(unique(dat$symbol))  ## [1] "JTSJOL" "PAYEMS" "UNRATE"  # Data for recession shading recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") tail(recess)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01 0 ## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01 0 ## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01 0 ## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01 0 ## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01 0 ## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01 0  recess_dat <- recess %>% arrange(date) %>% mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% # Filter only recessions filter(price == 1) recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% group_by(era) %>% # Unncessary, but to be sure... arrange(date) %>% filter(row_number() == 1 | row_number() == n()) # Now reshape the data wide. # Each row will contain the start and end dates of a recession. recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% mutate(junk = row_number()) %>% mutate(begin_end = case_when( junk == 1 ~ "begin", junk == 2 ~ "end" )) recess_wide <- recess_dat %>% ungroup() %>% select(symbol, price, date, era, begin_end) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = begin_end, values_from = date)  Here is the unemployment-rate series:
dat_ur <- filter(dat, symbol == "UNRATE") ggplot(data = dat_ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price)) + geom_rect(data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat_ur$date)), mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf), fill = "blue", alpha = 0.2) + xlab("") + ylab("Percent") + ggtitle("Unemployment rate")  Here is the vacancy-rate series:
dat_wide <- dat %>% pivot_wider(names_from = symbol, values_from = price) %>% mutate(vac = 100*JTSJOL / (JTSJOL + PAYEMS)) %>% drop_na(vac) tail(dat_wide)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 5 ## date JTSJOL PAYEMS UNRATE vac ## <date> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 2019-09-01 7046 151368 3.5 4.45 ## 2 2019-10-01 7309 151553 3.6 4.60 ## 3 2019-11-01 6793 151814 3.5 4.28 ## 4 2019-12-01 6552 151998 3.5 4.13 ## 5 2020-01-01 7012 152212 3.6 4.40 ## 6 2020-02-01 6882 152487 3.5 4.32  ggplot(data = dat_wide) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = vac)) + geom_rect(data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat_wide$date)), mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf), fill = "blue", alpha = 0.2) + xlab("") + ylab("Percent") + ggtitle("Vacancy rate")  Here’s the Beveridge curve:
# Subset based on last recession latest_recess <- max(recess_wide$begin) dat_wide <- dat_wide %>% mutate(late = case_when( date >= latest_recess ~ paste(month(latest_recess, label = TRUE), year(latest_recess), "on"), TRUE ~ "Early period")) ggplot(dat_wide) + geom_path(mapping = aes(x = UNRATE, y = vac), color = "gray") + geom_point(mapping = aes(x = UNRATE, y = vac, color = late)) + guides(color = FALSE) + xlab("Unemployment rate") + ylab("Job vacancy rate") + ggtitle("Beveridge curve") + scale_color_viridis(discrete=TRUE) + theme_bw()

content:
Here are data from the latest Employment Situation.
Unemployment rate or number of unemployed as a percentage of the labor force:
# Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) mygray <- "gray66" ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01") ur <- ur %>% mutate(series = "Unemployment rate") last_date <- max(ur$date) last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]] ggplot(data = ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.1, color = mygray) + # Highlight last observation geom_point(data = filter(ur, date == last_date), mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 5) + xlab("") + ylab("Percent") + ggtitle("Unemployment rate") + # Label y-axis for wsj theme scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(4, 6, 8, 10), labels = c("4", "6", "8", "10%")) + # Label last observation annotate("text", x = last_date, y = last_lvl, label = paste0(last_lvl), color = "black", vjust = -1.5) + # Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray color theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12)  The unemployment rate was last_lvl.
payems <- tq_get("PAYEMS", get = "economic.data", from = "2002-12-01") payems <- payems %>% mutate(change_jobs = price - lag(price), mycat = date == max(date)) %>% filter(!is.na(change_jobs)) last_date <- max(payems$date) last_lvl <- payems$change_jobs[[which(payems$date == max(payems$date))]] segment_height <- 100 # Set up labels for y axis my_breaks <- seq(from = -800, to = 400, by = 200) my_labels <- paste(my_breaks) my_labels[[length(my_labels)]] <- paste(my_labels[[length(my_labels)]], "thousand") ggplot(data = payems) + geom_col(mapping = aes(x = date, y = change_jobs, color = mycat, fill = mycat), inherit.aes = FALSE) + scale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks, labels = my_labels, limits = c(-800, 400)) + # Label last observation annotate("text", x = last_date - 700, y = last_lvl, label = paste0("-", last_lvl, "\n March 2020"), color = "black") + # + # annotate("segment", x = last_date, xend = last_date, # y = last_lvl, yend = last_lvl + segment_height - 25, # linetype = "dashed") + # Color the bars scale_fill_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) + scale_color_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) + # Turn off legend guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) + ggtitle("Monthly change in jobs") + theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12) + # Put grid lines on top theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = NA), panel.ontop = TRUE)  ## Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values (position_stack).

content:
Here are initial-claims data, which were covered in a recent NY Times article. I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article.
Data on initial claims are available at FRED by browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claims and selecting Initial Claims.
Here is the R code for retrieving and plotting these data. Data on initial claims from March are highlighted in orange.
# Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) my_blue <- "purple1" my_orange <- "orangered1" my_shade <- "gray66" claims <- tq_get("ICSA", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") head(claims)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 ICSA 1967-01-07 208000 ## 2 ICSA 1967-01-14 207000 ## 3 ICSA 1967-01-21 217000 ## 4 ICSA 1967-01-28 204000 ## 5 ICSA 1967-02-04 216000 ## 6 ICSA 1967-02-11 229000  tail(claims)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 ICSA 2020-02-22 220000 ## 2 ICSA 2020-02-29 217000 ## 3 ICSA 2020-03-07 211000 ## 4 ICSA 2020-03-14 282000 ## 5 ICSA 2020-03-21 3307000 ## 6 ICSA 2020-03-28 6648000  # Convert claims to millions dat <- claims %>% mutate(price = price / 1e+06) dat_early <- dat %>% filter( date >= ymd("2004-01-01") & date < ymd("2020-03-01")) dat_late <- dat %>% filter(date >= ymd("2020-03-01")) last_date <- max(dat_late$date) last_lvl <- dat_late$price[[which(dat_late$date == max(dat_late$date))]] my_breaks <- seq(0,7) my_labels <- paste(my_breaks) my_labels[[length(my_labels)]] <- "7 million" plt <- ggplot() + geom_col(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), data = dat_early, color = my_blue, position = "identity") + # Highlight March 2020 geom_col(data = dat_late, mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), color = my_orange) + xlab("") + ggtitle("Initial jobless claims") + # Label y-axis for wsj theme scale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks, labels = my_labels, limits = c(0,7.5)) + # Label last observation, set off 1 year annotate("text", x = last_date - 360, y = last_lvl, label = paste0(last_lvl, "\n", month(last_date, label = TRUE), ", ", day(last_date)), color = my_orange, hjust = 0.85) + # Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray color theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans") # Display the plot (plt)  FRED also provides recession dates. These dates can be used to add recession shading to the developing figure.
The goal is highlighting recessions. From the NBER’s website:
 Contractions (recessions) start at the peak of a business cycle and end at the trough.
 Note: The FRED series USRECM indicates periods “from the peak through the trough”; whereas, USREC indicates periods “from the period following the peak through the trough.” (Both series are monthly.)
recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") tail(recess)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01 0 ## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01 0 ## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01 0 ## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01 0 ## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01 0 ## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01 0  To use geom_rect(), the beginning and end of recessions are needed.
# Create groups based recessions recess_dat <- recess %>% arrange(date) %>% mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% # Filter only recessions filter(price == 1)  Now the recessions are grouped according to era. The following code groups the data by recessions and keeps the first and last element of the group.
recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% group_by(era) %>% # Unncessary, but to be sure... arrange(date) %>% filter(row_number() == 1 | row_number() == n()) # Now reshape the data wide. # Each row will contain the start and end dates of a recession. recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% mutate(junk = row_number()) %>% mutate(begin_end = case_when( junk == 1 ~ "begin", junk == 2 ~ "end" )) recess_wide <- recess_dat %>% ungroup() %>% select(symbol, price, date, era, begin_end) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = begin_end, values_from = date)  We can check these dates against the official dates published at the NBER’s website.
tail(recess_wide)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 5 ## symbol price era begin end ## <chr> <int> <dbl> <date> <date> ## 1 USRECM 1 56 1973-11-01 1975-03-01 ## 2 USRECM 1 58 1980-01-01 1980-07-01 ## 3 USRECM 1 60 1981-07-01 1982-11-01 ## 4 USRECM 1 62 1990-07-01 1991-03-01 ## 5 USRECM 1 64 2001-03-01 2001-11-01 ## 6 USRECM 1 66 2007-12-01 2009-06-01  These dates agree with the NBER dates.
Adding recession shading is straightforward:
plt2 <- plt + geom_rect(mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = 0, ymax = 7), data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat_early$date)), fill = my_shade, alpha = 0.6) (plt2)  To get a sense of the initial claims, here are all the data:
ggplot() + geom_rect(mapping = aes(xmin = begin, xmax = end, ymin = 0, ymax = 7), data = filter(recess_wide, begin >= min(dat$date)), fill = my_shade, alpha = 0.6) + geom_col(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), data = dat, color = my_blue, position = "identity") + xlab("") + ggtitle("Initial jobless claims") + # Label y-axis for wsj theme scale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks, labels = my_labels, limits = c(0,7.5)) + theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans")
summary:

Data on initial claims are available at FRED by browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claims and selecting Initial Claims.
Here is the R code for retrieving and plotting these data. Data on initial claims from March are highlighted in orange.
title: Initial Claims

content:
Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. These graphs attempt to replicate those published by the NY Times.
Unemployment rate or number of unemployed as a percentage of the labor force:
# Load packages library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) mygray <- "gray66" ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01") ur <- ur %>% mutate(series = "Unemployment rate") last_date <- max(ur$date) last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]] ggplot(data = ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.1, color = mygray) + # Highlight last observation geom_point(data = filter(ur, date == last_date), mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 5) + xlab("") + ylab("Percent") + ggtitle("Unemployment rate") + # Label y-axis for wsj theme scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(4, 6, 8, 10), labels = c("4", "6", "8", "10%")) + # Label last observation annotate("text", x = last_date, y = last_lvl, label = paste0(last_lvl), color = "black", vjust = -1.5) + # Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray color theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12)  The unemployment rate was last_lvl.
payems <- tq_get("PAYEMS", get = "economic.data", from = "2016-11-01") payems <- payems %>% mutate(change_jobs = price - lag(price), mycat = date == max(date)) %>% filter(!is.na(change_jobs)) last_date <- max(payems$date) last_lvl <- payems$change_jobs[[which(payems$date == max(payems$date))]] segment_height <- 100 ggplot(data = payems) + geom_col(mapping = aes(x = date, y = change_jobs, color = mycat, fill = mycat), inherit.aes = FALSE) + scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(100, 200, 300, 400), labels = c("100", "200", "300", "400 thousand"), limits = c(0, 400)) + # Label last observation annotate("text", x = last_date, y = last_lvl + segment_height, label = paste0("+", last_lvl, "\nNov 2019"), color = "black") + annotate("segment", x = last_date, xend = last_date, y = last_lvl, yend = last_lvl + segment_height - 25, linetype = "dashed") + # Color the bars scale_fill_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) + scale_color_manual(values = c(mygray, "black")) + # Turn off legend guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) + ggtitle("Monthly change in jobs") + theme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans", base_size = 12) + # Put grid lines on top theme(panel.background = element_rect(fill = NA), panel.ontop = TRUE)

Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. These graphs attempt to replicate those published by the NY Times.

# Load packages library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) mygray <- "gray66" ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01") ur <- ur %>% mutate(series = "Unemployment rate") last_date <- max(ur$date) last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]] ggplot(data = ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.

content:
Introduction This is an example of using R to run many regressions and collect a single regression coefficient from each model. The code uses R’s list-columns feature.
Data library(forcats) library(tidyquant) date_start <- "1960-01-01" dat <- tq_get(c("UNRATE", "CPIAUCSL", "CPILFESL"), get = "economic.data", from = date_start) ur <- dat %>% filter(symbol == "UNRATE") %>% rename(ur = price) %>% select(-symbol) dat <- filter(dat, symbol != "UNRATE")  Check that the unemployment-rate data are read in correctly:
head(ur)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 2 ## date ur ## <date> <dbl> ## 1 1960-01-01 5.2 ## 2 1960-02-01 4.8 ## 3 1960-03-01 5.4 ## 4 1960-04-01 5.2 ## 5 1960-05-01 5.1 ## 6 1960-06-01 5.4  tail(ur)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 2 ## date ur ## <date> <dbl> ## 1 2018-12-01 3.9 ## 2 2019-01-01 4 ## 3 2019-02-01 3.8 ## 4 2019-03-01 3.8 ## 5 2019-04-01 3.6 ## 6 2019-05-01 3.6  Generate inflation data as percent change from one year ago:
$$ \text{percent change from year ago} = \left( \frac{ x_t }{ x_{t-12} } - 1 \right) \times 100. $$
dat <- dat %>% group_by(symbol) %>% mutate(infl = (price/lag(price, n = 12) - 1)*100) %>% drop_na() # Rename series dat <- dat %>% mutate(series_name = case_when(symbol == "CPILFESL" ~ "Less food and energy", symbol == "CPIAUCSL" ~ "All items"))  Plot the data:
ggplot(data = dat) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = infl, color = series_name)) + labs(x = "", y = "Percent", color = "") + ggtitle("Inflation") + theme_bw()  Regressions The goal now is seeing the relationship between the unemployment rate and inflation. Specifically, we’re interested in the regressions $$ \text{inflation}_t = \alpha + \beta \; \text{unemployment rate}_t + \varepsilon_t $$ for each of the inflation series. We’re interested in reporting the $ \beta $s.
To do so, we need to get the data in this form:
dat <- dat %>% left_join(ur, by = "date") head(dat)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 6 ## # Groups: symbol [1] ## symbol date price infl series_name ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> ## 1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01 29.8 1.60 All items 6.6 ## 2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01 29.8 1.46 All items 6.9 ## 3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01 29.8 1.46 All items 6.9 ## 4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01 29.8 0.914 All items 7 ## 5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01 29.8 0.913 All items 7.1 ## 6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01 29.8 0.777 All items 6.9  tail(dat)  ## # A tibble: 6 x 6 ## # Groups: symbol [1] ## symbol date price infl series_name ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <chr> <dbl> ## 1 CPILFESL 2018-12-01 260. 2.21 Less food and energy 3.9 ## 2 CPILFESL 2019-01-01 261. 2.15 Less food and energy 4 ## 3 CPILFESL 2019-02-01 261. 2.08 Less food and energy 3.8 ## 4 CPILFESL 2019-03-01 261. 2.04 Less food and energy 3.8 ## 5 CPILFESL 2019-04-01 262. 2.07 Less food and energy 3.6 ## 6 CPILFESL 2019-05-01 262. 2.00 Less food and energy 3.6  Now we’re interested in a function that regresses infl on ur and returns the coefficient on ur. The input of the function will be data frame. We’re interested in data frames because there are essentially two datasets, one for each of the inflation series. This is done using R’s nest, which creates a new data structure:
dat <- dat %>% group_by(series_name) %>% nest() dat  ## # A tibble: 2 x 2 ## series_name data ## <chr> <list> ## 1 All items <tibble [701 x 5]> ## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]>  Each row of the data column is data frame:
dat$data[[1]]  ## # A tibble: 701 x 5 ## symbol date price infl ur ## <chr> <date> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 CPIAUCSL 1961-01-01 29.8 1.60 6.6 ## 2 CPIAUCSL 1961-02-01 29.8 1.46 6.9 ## 3 CPIAUCSL 1961-03-01 29.8 1.46 6.9 ## 4 CPIAUCSL 1961-04-01 29.8 0.914 7 ## 5 CPIAUCSL 1961-05-01 29.8 0.913 7.1 ## 6 CPIAUCSL 1961-06-01 29.8 0.777 6.9 ## 7 CPIAUCSL 1961-07-01 29.9 1.25 7 ## 8 CPIAUCSL 1961-08-01 29.9 1.11 6.6 ## 9 CPIAUCSL 1961-09-01 30.0 1.25 6.7 ## 10 CPIAUCSL 1961-10-01 30.0 0.773 6.5 ## # ... with 691 more rows  Now we’re interested in a function that takes one of these data frames as inputs.
my_reg <- function(df) { fit <- lm(infl ~ ur, data = df) # Return the unemployment-rate coefficient return(fit$coefficients[["ur"]]) }  And we want to use R’s map function to return the coefficients:
dat <- dat %>% mutate(coefficient = map(data, my_reg)) %>% unnest(coefficient) dat  ## # A tibble: 2 x 3 ## series_name data coefficient ## <chr> <list> <dbl> ## 1 All items <tibble [701 x 5]> 0.230 ## 2 Less food and energy <tibble [701 x 5]> 0.371  The dataset now contains the coefficients from the two regressions.

Data library(forcats) library(tidyquant) date_start <- "1960-01-01" dat <- tq_get(c("UNRATE", "CPIAUCSL", "CPILFESL"), get = "economic.data", from = date_start) ur <- dat %>% filter(symbol == "UNRATE") %>% rename(ur = price) %>% select(-symbol) dat <- filter(dat, symbol != "UNRATE")  Check that the unemployment-rate data are read in correctly:

Another big selling point was the inclusion of R code in posts, a feature that I quickly became accostomed to after writing a couple of course websites in R Markdown and publishing them with GitHub Pages.1
The following sections cover some neat features.
Footnotes Footnotes are easy to include—just like this.2
Footnotes are easy to include---just like this.[^fn:fn-example]  $ \LaTeX{} $ Including inline $ \LaTeX{} $ math is done by wrapping expressions in a single $. Multiline expressions are wrapped in $$. For example,
$$ \begin{equation} \label{eq:some-eq} \mathbf{y} = \mathbf{X} \beta + \varepsilon, \end{equation} $$
which can be referred to as $ \eqref{eq:some-eq} $. Automatic equation numbering is accomplished by including the HTML code

content:
Are people who “run their own business” included in the Current Employment Statistics program? It depends.
Background on the CES Usually on the first Friday of each month the Bureau of Labor Statistics releases data on current employment in the “Employment Situation.” The quoted level of employment comes from the Current Employment Statistics survey, aka the establishment or payroll survey.
Getting data on the level of employment should be doable because these data are collected for tax purposes. “Unemployment Insurance (UI) is a federal–state program jointly financed through Federal and state employer payroll taxes (federal/state UI tax). Generally, employers must pay both state and Federal unemployment taxes if: (1) they pay wages to employees totaling $1,500, or more, in any quarter of a calendar year; or, (2) they had at least one employee during any day of a week during 20 weeks in a calendar year, regardless of whether or not the weeks were consecutive. However, some state laws differ from the Federal law and employers should contact their state workforce agencies to learn the exact requirements.”1 In Rhode Island, for example, employers of one or more workers are subject to the Employment Security and the Temporary Disability Insurance Acts. Anyone subject to these acts will be taxed and have their data collected by the state of RI. These data are then compiled by the state of Rhode Island and reported to the Bureau of Labor Statistics in something called the ES-202 Report.
From these state-level data, which are at the UI account number, the CES creates a sampling frame. The CES sampling method is based on state, industry, and employment size—in other words, the CES wants to make sure it’s hitting industry and employment numbers at the state level. The sample is updated twice a year using updated UI-based universe data, providing information on firm births and deaths, which is something macroeconomists are into.2
Once the sampling frame is set, the BLS attempts to collect data from the sample of establishments. The BLS encourages participation by tailoring their data collection to what the firm prefers. Initially each firm is called. Then data are collected according to something called Computer Assisted Telephone Interviewing, which hopefully leads to self-reporting.
Fun fact: “Very large, multiestablishment firms are often enrolled via personal visit, and ongoing reporting is established via electronic data interchange,” which are apparently “electronic files.”3
The CES survey sample includes about 160,000 US firms and covers about 400,000 worksites.
That all seems perfectly clear, but the edges seem a little funny. For example, chapter 2 of the BLS Handbook of Methods states that domestic workers in private homes are excluded from the CES survey. But in Rhode Island, employers of domestic workers who have paid $1,000 or more in total cash wages in any calendar quarter are subject to UI tax.4 I’m not sure if the Rhode Island employers of domestic workers can be part of the CES sample. Also, the crew of a fishing boat made up of less than 10 people whose sole remuneration is a share of the catch are not counted. I don’t know if this is a state-level thing, decided by state legislators. This fuzziness might explain the 97 percent coverage rate of the CES.
Answer to the question If the 10 people running their own business in question 9 of Mankiw 9e, p 45 are paying UI taxes and the business is incorporated, then they are counted as employed in the establishment survey. If they own a fishing vessel in the state of Rhode Island and pay their crew according to a lay system (see Moby-Dick where Ishmael secured the 300th lay or 1⁄300 of net profits—Queequeg secured the 90th lay), then no.
If the person running their own business is doing it through 1099s or if the business is unincorporated, then they would not be counted in the establishment survey. The unincorporated self-employed are not counted in the establishment survey.
And that’s why you could make a case that the answer to 9 is either 55 or 65.
You can read even more about the details in Mary Bowler and Teresa L. Morisi’s article “Understanding the employment measures from the CPS and CES survey” published in the February 2006 issue of the Monthly Labor Review.
 You can find more information here^ You can read about this is the BLS Handbook of Methods.^ So like a spreadsheet? The documentation seems overly complicated here.^ This comes from the Rhode Island Employer Handbook here.^
summary: Are people who “run their own business” included in the Current Employment Statistics program? It depends.
title: On the establishment survey

content:
What are the units of the current-year GDP deflator? The answer is base-year dollars / current-year dollars.
In the first homework you calculated the implicit price deflator for GDP in an economy that produces and consumes hot dogs and hamburgers. Instead of hot dogs and hamburgers let’s agree to call them goods \( a \) and \(b \). The GDP deflator is
$$ \text{GPD Deflator} = \frac{\text{Nominal GDP}}{\text{Real GDP}} $$
summary: What are the units of the current-year GDP deflator? The answer is base-year dollars / current-year dollars.
title: What are the units of the GDP deflator?

content:
The difference between ex ante and ex post interest rates has to do with the Fisher equation. If you took a couple more macro classes after ECON 402, you’d expect the Fisher effect to be expressed as the relationship between the nominal interest rate and expected inflation:
$$ i_t = r_t + E_t \pi_{ t+1 }, $$
where \( E_t \) is the expectations operator conditional on all information available at time \( t \). Which simply means that the decision maker is using newspapers, FRED, the internet, etc. to make a guess about what they think inflation will be. The decision maker has to make a guess because they don’t know what inflation will be between time \( t \) and \( t+1 \).
Now think about a borrower and a lender deciding on the terms of a contract. The number written on the contract is a nominal interest rate (usually, not always). And to get that number they need to agree on a forecast of inflation. (The borrower may even welcome a high rate of interest if they thought their wages were going to rise significantly.) That means they have to form an expectation of inflation.
“The real interest rate that the borrower and lender expect when the load is made” is called the ex ante real interest rate. As time passes and people make decisions in the economy, prices are realized, which determine the actual rate of inflation. “The real interest rate that is actually realized” is called the ex post interest rate. This can only be inferred after the fact. See p. 117 of Mankiw, 9e.
When Chair Ben Bernanke came to U-M, he talked about “open mouth operations,” a play on open-market operations, which are the usual puchases and sales of government bonds that the Fed makes. Because interest rates were pinned at zero, Chair Berenanke talked about lowering real interest rates by increasing inflation expectations:
$$ r_t = i_t - E_t \pi_{t+1}. $$
Chair Bernanke talked about promising not to raise interest rates—no matter what—which would increase \( E_t \pi_{t+1} \) thereby lowering \( r_t \). It was pretty clear Chair Bernanke had the Fisher effect in mind.
There’s nothing deep behind the terms ex ante interest rate and ex post interest rate. And, in fact, it’s even messier in practice—what interest rate and what measure of inflation? There are lots of interest rates and several measures of inflation.

content:
The 2015 midterm from 605 features a functional equation of the form
$$ V(k,p,s) = \max \left\{ V_{\text{trade}},V_{\text{no trade}} \right\}, $$
where
$$ V_{\text{trade}} = u(k^{N}) - pk^{N} + spk^{N} + \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k^{N}(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$
and
$$ V_{\text{no trade}} = u(k) + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$
This post goes through how you can establish that there exists a unique solution to the functional equation.
The details are provided on the exam. Here’s a sketch of a proof that establishes that there is a unique solution to the Bellman equation.
The \( T \) operator Let \(B(\Psi) \) denote the set of bounded functions \( R: \Psi \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) equipped with the \( \sup \) norm \( \lVert R \rVert = \sup_{\psi \in \Psi} R(\psi) \).
Define the operator \(T\) on \(B(\Psi)\) as
\begin{align*} (TR)(k,p,s) = \max_{\text{trade}, \text{no trade}} \Bigg\{ &u(k^{N}) - pk^{N} + spk^{N} + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ R(k^{N}(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right], \\\\ & u(k) + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ R(k(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] \Bigg\}. \end{align*}
We’re going to show that \(T\) maps the set of bounded functions into bounded functions and verify that it satisfies the monotonicity and discounting hypotheses of Blackwell’s sufficient conditions for a contraction (theorem 5.11). Because \( B(\Psi) \) is a complete normed vector space (theorem 5.8), the contraction mapping theorem (theorem 5.10) admits one and only one fixed point \( R^{\star} \in B(\Psi) \).1
Bounded to bounded Take any \( R \in B(\Psi) \). Since \( R \) is bounded, there exist \( \underline{R} \) and \( \overline{R} \) such that \( \underline{R} \leq R(\psi) \leq \overline{R} \) for all \( \psi \).
Then
\begin{aligned} (TR)(k,p,s) &= \max_{\text{trade}, \text{no trade}} \Bigg\{ &&u(k^{N}) - pk^{N} + spk^{N} + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ R(k^{N}(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right], \\\\ &&& u(k) + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ R(k(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] \Bigg\} \\\\ &\leq \max_{\text{trade}, \text{no trade}} \Bigg\{ && u(k^{N}) + pk^{N} + \beta \overline{R}, \\\\ &&& u(k) + \beta \overline{R} \Bigg\}, \end{aligned}
where the last line uses properties of the stochastic process for \(s\). Then
\begin{aligned} (TR)(k,p,s) \leq u(k^{N}) + pk^{N} + \beta \overline{R}, \end{aligned}
assuming that \(u\) is increasing. As long as \(u\) is bounded (meaning \(u(k^{N}) < M\) for some \(M \in \mathbb{R} \)), we’ve established that \(T\) is bounded above.
Along the same lines,
\begin{align} (TR)(k,p,s) \geq \max_{\text{trade}, \text{no trade}} \Bigg\{ &u(k^{1}) - pk^{N} + \beta \underline{R}, \\\\ &u(k^{1}) + \beta \underline{R} \Bigg\} \end{align}
where \( k^{1} \) is the lowest level of capital in the discrete state space, establishing a lower bound for \( T \). Therefore \(T\) is a self map, mapping bounded functions to bounded functions.
Satisfying Blackwell’s sufficiency conditions for a contraction Because the space of bounded functions is complete, if we can show that \(T\) satisfies Blackwell’s sufficiency conditions for a contraction, we’ll have a contraction mapping on a complete metric space. The contraction mapping theorem tells us that \(T\) has exactly one fixed point and gives us a bound for how close we are to the exact solution using the method of successive approximation.
Monotonicity looks straightforward. How about discounting? That?s going to be easy too. For any \(c \geq 0\), the \( \beta c \) part is going to come out of both expectations for the trade and no-trade options. Remark 5.8 of the ECON 605 Leahy notes applies.
I was very lose with defining the set \(\Psi \) and laying out the properties of \( u \), etc. These details, along with details about establishing monotonicity and discounting, are provided in several places in the notes. See, for example, Remark 5.8; sections 6.1, 6.2, and 6.4; the introduction to Section 11; and section 11.2. Those parts of the notes apply the theorems more rigorously. This post is meant to be a sketch.
-- --  MathJax.Hub.Config({ tex2jax: { inlineMath: [['$','$'], ['\\(','\\)']], displayMath: [['$$','$$'], ['\[','\]']], processEscapes: true, processEnvironments: true, skipTags: ['script', 'noscript', 'style', 'textarea', 'pre'], TeX: { equationNumbers: { autoNumber: "AMS" }, extensions: ["AMSmath.js", "AMSsymbols.js"] } } });   All references to theorems refer to the ECON 605 Leahy notes.^
summary:
The 2015 midterm from 605 features a functional equation of the form
$$ V(k,p,s) = \max \left\{ V_{\text{trade}},V_{\text{no trade}} \right\}, $$
where
$$ V_{\text{trade}} = u(k^{N}) - pk^{N} + spk^{N} + \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k^{N}(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$
and
$$ V_{\text{no trade}} = u(k) + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$
This post goes through how you can establish that there exists a unique solution to the functional equation.
title: A functional equation

content:
Notes on economies under the rubric of classical monetary models were added to the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. They are included in section section 9, which is new.
A couple of ideas worth considering:
 Remark 9.14 suggests that technology is largely ignorable since we can work with a transformed model. The only catch is that \( N_{t} = 1 \), which might seem awkward at first. But remember: we still need to distinguish labor supply from labor demand (see, for example, remark 2.2 of the ECON 605 Stolyarov notes). Remark 9.12 goes through market clearing when money growth is constant. Starting from the household’s budget constraint, which is normally ignored by appealing to Walras’s law (see section 3 of the ECON 607 Leahy notes), we can derive the material-balance condition for the economy, establishing that one of the equations is redundant. How does money grow at a constant rate? The notes go through the case where the government’s only function is printing money that is transferred to the household through lump-sum transfers. Here’s the open question: what happens when the ownership of capital is transferred to firms that produce the final good (using no labor)? This market structure adds a variation to the list in remark 3.1 of the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. Remark 3.4 of the ECON 607 Leahy notes talks about this idea too. It will use the machinery in section 3.1.4.3 of the ECON 607 Ottonello notes.1 You should see it right away—if not, let me know and we’ll get it straightened out.  Keep grinding. You’re almost there.
 I mistakenly said this was like a capital-leasing firm in an earlier version of this post. Of course not: the firm produces bananas; it does not rent bricks to banana-producing firms. This was corrected on 7⁄18 at 6:40 pm 📯 📝^

content:
A few examples dealing with lag operators were added to the ECON 605 Leahy notes. They go through the “forward” and “backward” solutions to first-order linear difference equations and are included in section 2, “Practice with the lag operator,” which is new.
I also added Monday office hours from 1:00–3:00 pm in Foster library. They are listed under MacroSquad. We’ll try out this time and adjust accordingly.
These notes mostly come from chapter 2 of James Hamilton’s Time Series Analysis. They were motivated by the proposed solutions to the 2011 midterm. Michael alerted me to some dubious algebra there and we came up with a few notes on the inverse operator that is seemingly used in the solution.1 The result is a very useful framework for solving linear difference equations.
Consider the difference equation
\begin{align*} y_{t} = \phi y_{t-1} + w_{t}. \end{align*}
Using the lag operator we can write this as
\begin{align*} (1 - \phi L) y_{t} = w_{t}. \end{align*}
When $ | \phi | < 1 $ we had the cool inverse result, which we used to get the Wold representation of a time series in section 1:2
\begin{align*} (1 - \phi L)^{-1} = (1 + \phi L + \phi^{2}L^{2} + \phi^{3}L^{3} + \cdots ). \end{align*}
But what happens when $ | \phi | > 1 $? Hamilton cites Sargent who suggests solving the difference equation forward by applying the inverse operator
\begin{align*} (1 - \phi L)^{-1} &= \frac{- \phi^{-1}L^{-1}}{1 - \phi^{-1}L^{-1}} \\ &= - \phi^{-1}L^{-1} \left( 1 + \phi^{-1}L^{-1} + \phi^{-2}L^{-2} + \phi^{-3}L^{-3} + \cdots \right), \end{align*}
where $ L^{-1} x_{t} = x_{t+1} $, $ L^{-2} x_{t} = x_{t+2} $, etc. In other words, you solve the difference equation forward as opposed to backward.
The details are included in section 2 of the ECON 605 Leahy notes. The example from the 2011 midterm leads to a very cool interpretation of the benefit of hiring a worker—it’s proportional to the discounted sum of the differences between the value of output and the wage. There’s also an example based on, of course, Jorgenson’s formula ✨

Notes on the 607 final were added to the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. They are included in section section 12, under the part titled “Odds and ends”.
Section 12.1 is on the efficiency of directed search and relies on the ideas developed in section 8, except that instead of wages being a fraction of output, wages are now a convex combination of output and the worker’s outside option:
$$ w = s(\theta)y + [1 - s(\theta)] b, $$
where \( s(\theta) \) is the worker’s share in creating a match. Pretty nifty.
Section 12.2 talks about the “superneutrality” of a steady state where money is growing at a constant rate.

content:
A few people have asked me whether or not \( \tilde{k} \) jumps in the F2014 midterm. It does. Does that mean the stock of capital jumps? What about \(k\)?
Showing that \(\tilde{k}\) jumps I think the confusion arises because my notes on the problem look at properties of \(\ln y \equiv \ln \left( Y / L \right) \) instead of \(\tilde{k}\). The question asks about the time series of \(\ln y \). But these two quantities, of course, are related.
To show that \(\tilde{k}\) jumps we can proceed just like we do on page 12 of the review. Something happens at time \(T\) and we’re interested in showing that \(\tilde{k}\) jumps up:
\begin{align*} \tilde{k}(T+0) > \tilde{k}(T-0). \end{align*}
Here’s the key: we need to know that \(h, \; K, \; N, \; A \) are all stock variables that do not jump. This idea is stated in the review on page 12.
So. Plugging in, we have
\begin{align*} \tilde{k}(T+0) &> \tilde{k}(T-0) \\\\ \iff K(T+0)/Z(T+0)N(T+0) &> K(T-0)/Z(T-0)N(T-0) \\\\ \iff Z(T+0)^{-1} &> Z(T-0)^{-1} \\\\ \iff Z(T-0) &> Z(T+0), \end{align*}
as \(Z\) is going to be a positive number.
Plugging in for \(Z\) we have
\begin{align*} A(T-0)h(T-0)^{\frac{\gamma}{1-\alpha} + 1} &> A(T+0)h(T+0)^{\frac{\gamma^{\prime}}{1-\alpha} + 1} \\ \iff h^{\frac{\gamma}{1-\alpha} + 1} &> h^{\frac{\gamma^{\prime}}{1-\alpha} + 1} \\\\ \iff h^{\frac{\gamma}{1-\alpha}} &> h^{\frac{\gamma^{\prime}}{1-\alpha}}. \end{align*}
This is true because \(h^{x}\) is decreasing in \(x\) when \(h < 1\), a property established in the review notes. We’ve therefore established that \(\tilde{k} \) jumps up. 👍
The stock of capital does not jump Even though \(\tilde{k}\) jumps, the capital stock does not. We used this fact when we determined whether or not \(Y\) or \(\tilde{k}\) jumped. What about \(k \equiv K / N \)? No—both \(K\) and \(N\) are stocks. The reason \(\tilde{k}\), a nonstandard transformation of capital per effective worker, jumps is because a technological parameter increases in the normalization.
Stock variables will not jump for the most part. And when they do, you’ll know. For example, Professor Stolyarov will set Godzilla loose on the economy to destroy part of the capital stock 🏢 💥 💻 💥 or have a plague wreak havoc on the population, causing \(N\) to jump 💀
Here’s the handout.

content:
ECON 605 notes are uploaded and are available. The ECON 605 Stolyarov notes are available here. The ECON 605 Leahy notes are available here. I made several additions to both the Stolyarov and Leahy notes, which you might find helpful.
Here is a catalogue of the changes:
 Stolyarov notes:  The figures have been incorporated into the notes. By my count there are 61 new figures (11 from section 2, 1 from section 3, 10 from section 4, 6 from section 5, 16 from section 6, 7 from section 7, 2 from homework 3, 5 from homework 5, 3 from homework 6). Section 3 goes through an extended Uzawa theorem for the case when the machine that turns bananas into bricks improves over time. Section 8.1 discusses the correspondence between the class notes and chapter 9 in Acemoglu. In sections 9.2–9.5 of Acemoglu, the capital depreciation rate is 1. A consequence of this feature of the economy is that $ K_{t+1} = I_t $, making the supply of assets equal to investment. From 102 or proposition 1.1, we know saving equals investment, which makes the supply of assets equal to saving. In other words, for this special case, \(a_{t+1} L_{t} \) does indeed equal saving. But in general, when the capital depreciation rate does not equal one, \(a_{t+1} L_{t} \) does not equal saving. \(a_{t+1} L_{t} \) is the demand for assets and \( K_{t+1} = (1-\delta) K_{t} + I_{t} \) is the supply of assets. The only saving technology in the economy is capital, which takes the form of non-depreciated capital and new capital, or investment. This fact is discussed on slide 16 / 27 of Lecture_12_OLG_intro.pdf and exercise H6.2, item (b). Part 5 of the notes are answers to questions that I’ve written up since the end of the semester.  Leahy notes:  Section 14 provides some remarks about the final. These are not optimal answers in many ways, although they may offer some economic content. Section 3 considers the McCall search model without dynamic programing. It derives several comparative statics, including the effect that the flow value of unemployment and patience have on the reservation wage in sections 3.2.1 and 3.2.2. Section 3.2.3 allows for the possibility of quits. Section 3.4 derives the probability distribution of the waiting time until a job is accepted. The derivation uses a pretty, pretty, pretty cool variant of the geometric series. Comparative statics for the mean waiting time with respect to the flow benefit of unemployment and patience is given sections 3.4.2.1 and 3.4.2.2. Section 12.2.2 log-linearizes the continuous-time neoclassical growth model to illustrate you can just about log-linearize anything, which is a frequent solution technique in macro. Section 3.5 extends the McCall search model to allow for exogenous separations. It is shown that the reservation wage with separations is less than the reservation wage without separations—there is no reason to hold out for a high-paying job when there is a high probability that the job ends and the worker is forced to search for work through unemployment.    There are probably several other additions that I forgot to catalogue. And don’t forget that Parts 5 and 6 of the ECON 605 Leahy notes were primarily covered in ECON 607 with Professor Leahy, as 607 was a continuation of 605. Notes for the Stolyarov review are also posted here.

content: More detail can easily be written here using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: Person re-identification is a critical security task for recognizing a person across spatially disjoint sensors. Previous work can be computationally intensive and is mainly based on low-level cues extracted from RGB data and implemented on a PC for a fixed sensor network (such as traditional CCTV). We present a practical and efficient framework for mobile devices (such as smart phones and robots) where high-level semantic soft biometrics are extracted from RGB and depth data. By combining these cues, our approach attempts to provide robustness to noise, illumination, and minor variations in clothing. This mobile approach may be particularly useful for the identification of persons in areas ill-served by fixed sensors or for tasks where the sensor position and direction need to dynamically adapt to a target. Results on the BIWI dataset are preliminary but encouraging. Further evaluation and demonstration of the system will be available on our website.
title: A Person Re-Identification System For Mobile Devices

content: More detail can easily be written here using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.
summary: We present a mobile visual clothing search system whereby a smart phone user can either choose a social networking photo or take a new photo of a person wearing clothing of interest and search for similar clothing in a retail database. From the query image, the person is detected, clothing is segmented, and clothing features are extracted and quantized. The information is sent from the phone client to a server, where the feature vector of the query image is used to retrieve similar clothing products from online databases. The phone's GPS location is used to re-rank results by retail store location. State of the art work focuses primarily on the recognition of a diverse range of clothing offline and pays little attention to practical applications. Evaluated on a challenging dataset, the system is relatively fast and achieves promising results.
title: Mobile visual clothing search

content:
Here are initial-claims data,which were covered in a recent NY Times article.I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article.
Data on initial claims are available at FREDby browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claimsand selecting Initial Claims.
Here is the R code for retrieving these data:
# Load packageslibrary(tidyverse)## Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'tibble' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 3.6.3library(tidyquant)## Warning: package 'tidyquant' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'PerformanceAnalytics' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'xts' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'zoo' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'quantmod' was built under R version 3.6.3## Warning: package 'TTR' was built under R version 3.6.3library(ggplot2)library(ggthemes)my_blue <- "purple1"my_orange <- "orangered1"my_shade <- "gray66"claims <- tq_get("ICSA", get = "economic.data", from = "1900-01-01")head(claims)## # A tibble: 6 x 3## symbol date price## <chr> <date> <int>## 1 ICSA 1967-01-07 208000## 2 ICSA 1967-01-14 207000## 3 ICSA 1967-01-21 217000## 4 ICSA 1967-01-28 204000## 5 ICSA 1967-02-04 216000## 6 ICSA 1967-02-11 229000tail(claims)## # A tibble: 6 x 3## symbol date price## <chr> <date> <int>## 1 ICSA 2020-02-22 220000## 2 ICSA 2020-02-29 217000## 3 ICSA 2020-03-07 211000## 4 ICSA 2020-03-14 282000## 5 ICSA 2020-03-21 3307000## 6 ICSA 2020-03-28 6648000# Convert claims to millionsdat <- claims %>% mutate(price = price / 1e+06)dat_early <- dat %>% filter(date >= ymd("2004-01-01") &date < ymd("2020-03-01"))dat_late <- dat %>% filter(date >= ymd("2020-03-01"))last_date <- max(dat_late$date)last_lvl <- dat_late$price[[which(dat_late$date == max(dat_late$date))]]my_breaks <- seq(0,7)my_labels <- paste(my_breaks)my_labels[[length(my_labels)]] <- "7 million"plt <- ggplot(data = dat_early, aes(x = date, y = price)) +geom_col(color = my_blue, position = "identity") +# Highlight March 2020geom_col(data = dat_late,mapping = aes(x = date, y = price),color = my_orange) +xlab("") + ggtitle("Initial jobless claims") +# Label y-axis for wsj themescale_y_continuous(breaks = my_breaks,labels = my_labels, limits = c(0,7.5)) +# Label last observationannotate("text", x = last_date - 360,y = last_lvl, label = paste0(last_lvl, "\n", month(last_date, label = TRUE), ", ", day(last_date)),color = my_orange,hjust = 0.85) +# Use sans serif font instead of mono, use gray colortheme_wsj(base_family = "sans", color = "gray", title_family = "sans")
summary:
Here are initial-claims data,which were covered in a recent NY Times article.I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article.
Data on initial claims are available at FREDby browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claimsand selecting Initial Claims.
Here is the R code for retrieving these data:
# Load packageslibrary(tidyverse)## Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 3.
